results.notes: Growing singly in a mixed oak, birch, red maple, hemlock forest. Cap rosy pink with purplish tones, 11 cm. Cap does not bruise. Cap flesh pale yellow, immediately staining blue when cut. Tubes yellow, immediately bruise dark blue, 11 mm deep. Stipe 10 cm long, 2 cm thick at apex, 3 cm thick toward base but pinched right at the base. Yellow the entire length, reticulated throughout though not deeply, readily bruises blue. Stipe flesh color and stain like cap when cut, but shows a dark red stain in the base. Ammonia and KOH on flesh pale orange, dull yellowish on cap; Fe grayish on cap, negative on flesh. Spores narrowly ellipsoid, 9.3-10.6 × 2.8-3.4, means 10 (SD=0.4) x 3.2 (SD=0.2), n=37.

results.notes: Main branches much darker. Branches not constricted at attachment points. Regular, dichotomous. Base dark brown to nearly black. Short, shrubby, compact and upright thallus. Main branches with small fibrils and papillae. Irregularly segmented in terminal brabnches, but not distinctly cracked. Soralia very common, raised, occasionally tearing off cortex, half of branch width or less. Some of material hosting parasite (Biatoropsis usnearum, observation). Soralia abundant throughout, excavate when matured, with relatively thick margin and isidiomorphs present at least when young.

notes_fields.Comments:
From top to bottom, left to right:
Ganoderma sp. (Observation 324423); a cool round seed found on the beach and a hitchhiking New Mexican Geastrum; dried up Neonothopanus (Observation 324418); aerial rhizomorphs from Observation 324443; Botryobasidiaceae (Observation 324419); Auricularia, probably A. cornea (Observation 324420); snail shells; _Balansia gaduae (Observation 324412) and its possible anamorph/possible hyperparasite (Observation 324448) which are covering up our AirBnB Marasmius (Observation 324424); bigger snail shells; unk. sea treasure (alga?); anamorph from Observation 325479; cf. Lindquistia (Observation 324411); strange green thing (Observation 324442) which may or may not be the same as Observation 324441; Daldinia starbaeckii (Observation 324422); nectrioid w/ Tubercularia anamorph and a pretty, orange, nectriicolous Orbilia (Observation 325478) sharing a compartment with the box’s lone discomycete (Observation 324417); a green iguana jaw and some extra bits of Observation 324416 in the pill boxes; Moelleriella cf. epiphylla (Observation 324421) and more of Observation 324416

results.notes:
Fruiting at the base of a large, well rotted Douglas fir. Began monitoring this substrate last summer(2017) beginning in early August. Flushes on both sides of the log this season and abundant/caespitose primordial clusters forming.

Will continue monitoring and contributing images of growth for remainder of season.

Stems when very young(as seen here) are velvety and a deep purple hue. The color fades to a buff/tan color and a more suede like context with maturity.

Tapinella(and all members of the greater Paxillus, Neopaxillus, Panus, Panellus etc. group of fungi) are not recommended for the table and can accumulate toxins within the body resulting in death after only a few meals. Beautiful for photography, however.

Harvested/dehydrated 2 fruiting bodies for herbarium collection.

UPDATE ON 9/9/18: Almost exactly one month later the stems have faded from deep, velvety purple to the aforementioned coco brown. Still very densely hirsute(like crushed velvet). Caps still suede like and somewhat rubbery but much lighter in color. Size of caps at maturity are nearly the size of full dinner plates. Harvested one new fruiting body that was just a small primordial nub at the last encounter on 8/11/18(dehydrated and stored/labeled in my home herbarium). This complete observation shows all stages of growth, color context throughout the life cycle, habitat, preferred host tree(Douglas fir) in Washington state and behavior of the species throughout the fruiting cycle during summer here in the PNW. See all updated images from 9/9/18 added and labeled below.
results.location_name: Millersylvania State Park, Thurston Co., Washington, USA

results.notes:
A collection I have been monitoring for many years. Three large(still growing/sporulating) fruiting bodies from approximately 50 feet up to 80 feet up the Douglas fir substrate.

Images of the youngest and fastest growing sporophore show guttation in the morning sun.

results.notes:
Habitat: growing in heavily shaded cypress mulch at the base of a raised garden bed that is walled with southern yellow pine. (It’s producing a bumper harvest of cucumbers.)
Fruitbody: the large, sectioned spore case in the photo has a diameter of 3 cm. Exoperidium a dense reddish-brown fuzz aspiring to a height of 0.5 mm, which is also the thickness of the underlying shell of white peridium. When the fuzz is scraped away by fingernail, an underlying reticulate pattern appears, easily visible at 10×. In spent specimens the peridium remaining after spore discharge is dull ivory and wrinkled but not reticulate.
Spore color: olive brown

Although the growth on chips, fruitbody size, and crowded growth pattern are not a good match for typical L. subincarnatum, nothing else in Coker is a better fit. Is there a brown, Florida swamp species he overlooked?

results.notes:
In mixed woods, primarily beech/oak/eastern white pine. Caps ranging from 3 to 9 cm wide, convex, lacking conical bump in the center but sunken slightly instead. Chocolate brown, almost all specimens lightly mottled with light tan/white dots. Dry, soft, with a slightly inrolled margin. Gills white, fairly close, staining pink/brown with drying white latex. Stem light brown with white at base, dry, somewhat velvety. No odor.

I would have suggested L. lignyotus more definitively except that none of these specimens, even the most mature ones, had the conical bump I generally see with that species. In addition, it is difficult to determine whether the latex is staining the tissues pink or brown. If staining is brown, perhaps L. gerardii var. fagicola

results.notes:
A NEMF Foray collection for a MycoFlora sequencing project. NAMP collection MF54401.
A single fruiting body collected by Sue van Hook in deciduous woodlands under oaks. I saw this bolete right after it was found but I didn’t have my camera with me to take pix in the fresh state. By the time I got access to my camera, the mushroom was already faded and oxidized. My camera took lousy pix indoors, so I asked John Plischke to photograph it with his expensive gear.
This mushroom is 7 cm tall. The rich brick-red cap is 5.7 cm wide and 1.5 cm thick above the stipe; the yellow, irregularly-shaped pore mouths bruise blue and then brown; the greenish-yellow tubes are 5 mm deep, and also bruise blue; the tapering downward stipe with a yellow apex and flushed with red below is 5.5 cm long and 2 cm wide at the juncture with cap; the pale yellow dense flesh in the cap bluing light only right above the tubes, and the darker yellow flesh in the stipe not bluing at all.
DNA Sequencing Results & Discussion (posted on 25-Apr-21):
> This collection was ITS sequenced by MycoFlora in 2019. After a manual edit of the forward and reverse reads, the resultant consensus nrDNA sequence is 797 base pairs (bps) long. It consists of the last 46 bps of nrSSU, followed by a full-length nrITS region of 713 bps and then by the first 38 characters of nrLSU. The ITS1 and ITS2 subloci in this species are 236 and 316 nucleotides long, respectively; the 5.8S region sandwiched between the ITS spacers is of the standard conserved length of 161 bps. There are no ambiguities, it’s a single haplotype. The sequence has been accessioned in GenBank and just posted to this observation.
This collection is conspecific with another NEMF collection, obs 327973, by ITS (99.44% similar). There are four mismatches in the overlay of the full-length ITS sequences at positions nos. 66, 113, 417 and 622, two of which are ambiguities in MO327973 and the other two are pyrimidine-type (C/T) SNP events.
> A BLASTn-100 of the full-length ITS sequence recovered no matches or close hits. The top 4 accessions are only 90-91% similar, but query lengths don’t exceed 78%. Two of these are accessions of Hortiboletus coccyginus (KU144818 & KU144819), which make this rare bolete from the West Coast the closest relative in terms of genetic distance values.
> Looking at the morphology of this collection and the BLASTn profile, placement in Hortiboletus is a possibility. However, morphologically I wouldn’t call MO327553 / MO327973 a dead ringer for this genus. Furthermore, lack of Hortiboletus sp. hits from eastern North America is perplexing. For example, the full-length ITS sequence the common eastern Hortiboletus taxon, represented on MO by the sequenced obs 373444 and obs 418487, is only 81% similar.
> Based on the above information, provisional placement of this species into the subfamily Boletoideae seems more reasonable at this time. Further molecular research is needed for a phylogenetic placement at the genus level. However, since I deposited MO327553 and MO327973 at the NYBG herbarium, additional collections of this rare entity are required.

results.notes:
Original Notes:
A NEMF Foray collection for a MycoFlora sequencing project. NAMP collection MF54402.
Three large fruiting bodies growing in caespitose fashion collected by one N. Dingman near a hickory in grassland at the Hoagsback Overlook parking lot. There is some ambiguity to the location of the collection site, for Hoagsback Overlook parking is actually located on the east side near the Mt. Morris Dam, but the collector’s ID slip says “Letchworth-West”. Analysis of the park map revealed a small parking area on the west side near the overlook off Park Road at 42.7214929, -77.927476.
The overall morpho-gestalt was consistent with B. bicolor group, and the intact fruiting bodies didn’t have the characteristic odor of Lanmaoa pallidorosea, which is often misidentified as bicolor. The cut flesh, however, did have an distinct odor that was somewhat similar to L. pallidorosea.
The caps are 12 cm, 8.5 cm, and 7 cm wide. The stipes are 8 cm, 7.5 cm, and 6 cm long. The cross-sectioned specimen is the medium-sized one. The stipe width of the cut specimen is 3 cm at apex, narrowing to 2 cm near the base.

DNA Results & Discussion (posted on 25-Apr-21; updated on 26-Apr-21):
> This collection was sequenced by MycoFlora in 2019. After editing the raw forward and reverse read files, the assembled nrDNA sequence is 706 bps long. The full-length ITS locus is 658 base pairs (bps) long (ITS1 = 199 bps; 5.8S = 161 bps; ITS2 = 298 bps). The sequence is a joined contig of the forward and reverse reads because there are 2 points of heterogeneity in the ITS2 region. However, the scrambled region is only 6 nucleotides long, so solving this short puzzle to obtain one of the 4 possible haplotype combinations wasn’t particularly difficult. In addition, there are two ambiguous positions: “R” (A/G) in ITS1 sublocus and “Y” at the 5’ end in ITS2.
> A BLASTn search of the full-length ITS sequence gave two high-value hits:
GQ166877 = ‘Boletus bicolor voucher F:PRL5804MAN’ collected in Illinois (99.7% similarity and 100% query cover)
MN174798 = ‘Baorangia cf. bicolor voucher JLF6843’ collected by Dr. Jonathan Frank in Arizona (99.0% similarity, 94% query cover) and posted by him as obs 376427
I addition to these, a search of my personal database yielded the ITS of obs 333824 from VA (not yet disclosed or published).
Alignment of these four sequences is shown in Fig. 1. There are fourteen positions where differences are seen (counting is from the first base of ITS1): nos. 26, 92-93, 115, 157, 195, 376, 389, 408, 426, 434, 522, 614, and 657. However, nos. 115 and 389 involve ambiguities, while nos. 92-93, 408 and 426 are positions associated with variable length homo- and hetero-polymeric motifs; these are not real mismatches that can be disregarded. As of the remaining eight positions, as many as five of them are single nucleotide polymorphism events (SNPs) possibly showing a phylogeographic pattern between northern and southern vouchers, e.g., nos. 376, 434, and 522. The overall picture is indicative of a single phylogenetic species showing an expected intraspecific variability in the ITS region.
> As to the identity of this species, in short it’s neither Baorangia bicolor nor Lanmaoa pallidorosea, based on relevant ITS & LSU sequences found in GenBank and my personal database (undisclosed data). Suffice it to say that the LSU sequence of the AZ voucher places this taxon in Lanmaoa and also confirms that it’s very different from those of the two aforementioned taxa. Considering that B. bicolor and L. pallidorosea can easily be confused with each other in the field even by experienced pickers (vide supraand info in obs 423389), it wouldn’t come as a surprise that the present taxon may have been simply overlooked by professional mycologists of the past and never published. This notion is supported by the fact that Boletus pallidoroseus Both was published relatively recently (1998).
> At the present time, I would like to propose a placeholder name for this discrete phylogenetic species, Lanmaoa fallax I. Safonov & Kudzma. The Latin epithet means “deceptive” and refers to it similarity to Lanmaoa pallidorosea. In addition, both species have a potential of being misidentified as Baorangia bicolor.
As I no longer have this collection in my possession, the Virginia voucher will be sampled for additional loci in due course.

results.notes:
A NEMF Foray collection for a MycoFlora sequencing project. NAMP collection MF54404.
> Collected by Garrett Taylor (https://mushroomobserver.org/observer/show_user/3191) on his way to NEMF in deciduous woods of mostly red oak. The ID is by John R. Plischke, III and myself.
> The cap is ~12 cm wide and 2 cm thick above the stipe. The tubes are 3.5 mm deep. The stipe is 10 cm long, 4 cm wide at the apex, 3.5 cm wide midway, and 4 cm wide at the base. There was a distinct beef/chicken bouillon odor of the intact fruiting body. Overall the morphological gestalt is in good agreement with L. pallidorosea; however, the cap here is of an unusual deep purplish brick-red color, atypical of pallidorosea.
DNA Sequencing Results & Discussion (posted 25-Apr-21):
This collection was sequenced for ITS by MycoFlora/FunDiS. However, they gave up on the sequence because the forward and reverse reads both suffer from extensive heterogeneity that kicks in early on. Thus, I pieced this sequence by carefully resolving haplotypes in both directions by “eye-and-hand”.
Because of the presence of two points of heterogeneity, there are up to 4 haplotype combinations possible (22); the reported nrDNA sequence of 718 bps is just one of them. In both cases, the points of heterogeneity are located in homo-polymeric stretches of DNA and stem from insertion of extra bases in some ITS copies: “CCCCCC|C|” in ITS1 and “TTTT|T|” in ITS2. In addition to the general heteromorphy, there are 6 more single-base ambiguities present (all outside the heteromorphic area) — 4 early in ITS1 region and 2 in late ITS2 sublocus. The full-length ITS sequence is 664 nucleotides long.
The full-length ITS sequence is a good match to 11 accessions of Lanmaoa pallidorosea (98.0-99.8% similarity and 68-100% query cover). One of these accessions is associated with my own collection of L. pallidorosea, obs 247881 (99.3% face value similarity & 80% query cover).

Collected and identified by Robert Gergulics. No further details regarding this material or the collection site provided by the collector.
It appears that the original cap color was pale rose red. It faded to olive-brown from the disk toward the margins. The cracked caps are typical of Xerocomellus. The color of the flesh in the cracks is mostly pale yellow, but sometimes is pink. This is not X. chrysenteron, which is a European species, but it might be X. intermedius or a related taxon.
DNA Sequencing Results & Discussion (posted 28-Apr-21; edited 29-Apr-21):
> A clean and contiguous nrDNA sequence of 727 base pairs (bps) was obtained from this collection by MycoFlora, edited by me, and uploaded to this post (it has already been published in GenBank as accession #MW882069). Because of a single point of heterogeneity early in the ITS1 sublocus, at a poly-G homopolymer, the trace is not a consensus sequence, but the so-called “joined contig”; in other words, the forward and reverse read are “stitched” together at that point. The full-length nrITS locus is 674 nucleotides long in this species (ITS1 = 212 bps, 5.8S = 161 bps, ITS2 = 301 bps). There is a single ambiguity, “K” (G/T), in the ITS2 sublocus. The ITS spacer is preceded by the last 33 characters of nrSSU and followed by the first 20 bps of nrLSU.
> A BLASTn of the full-length ITS sequence gave 13 top hits having pairwise similarity of 97.8-99.85% with 88-100% query cover. One of these, #MW882070, is associated with another collection of this species recorded by me at the NEMF foray (from same walk!), obs 327629. Accessions with identification to species (6) are labeled as ‘Boletus/Xerocomellus chrysenteron’ or ‘cf./aff. chrysenteron’ and ‘Boletellus chrysenteroides’. I called mine ‘Xerocomellus cf. intermedius’, knowing for sure that this critter cannot be the European X. chrysenteron. Alignment of these sequences in MUSCLE (not shown here) suggests that most likely we’re dealing with the same phylogenetic entity endemic to North America (NA) and showing, as expected, intraspecific variability in the ITS spacer consisting of a combination of isolated and scattered ambiguities, single nucleotide polymorphism (SNP) events and gaps due to variable-length homopolymeric repeats; a few mismatches near either terminus can probably be attributed to poor read quality and possible editing errors. Ten vouchers originated from eastern NA, one was from Mexico, one from Canada and one was blank on geographic information.
> “Xerocomellus (Boletaceae) in western North America” by Frank et al. (2020) is the first major scientific publication sorting out this genus in the New World through the prism of DNA.1 The ITS tree in the paper includes only two species from eastern NA — one of them is Xerocomellus truncatus and the other is the present cryptic species (featuring the same GenBank accessions as those obtained from the BLASTn of MO327591); the authors label it as ‘Xerocomellus “chrysenteron” eNA’. The closes genetic relative is Xerocomellus diffractus from western NA.
The authors also state that “It appears that Xerocomellus species richness is greater in western North America than in eastern North America, and no Xerocomellus species are presently known to occur across the entire North American continent”. While, it’s indeed going to be difficult, if not impossible, to match, let alone exceed, the diversity of western NA Xerocomellus in the East, the “right half” of the country probably has more than just 2-3 species/OTUs known to exist.
Reference:
1 Free access at https://www.researchgate.net/...

These seem to be prolific in this area this year.
Field guides typically list it as having no odor, and most people agree. Some people report light, sweet odor. As it turns out, its actually the stinkiest mushroom Ive ever come across, but only SOME people can smell it! Its so strong I can smell it from several feet away and through a sealed ziplock baggie.
I had a sample and 20 willing, perhaps reluctant, participants all smell the same sample. Of them, only myself and one little boy could smell it. It is a pungent, minty, chemically smell, reminiscent of camphor. (The little boy described it as peppermint.) Its so strong I can smell it from several feet away and through a sealed ziplock baggie. Since then, I regularly poll people when they find it, and have had several smaller groups of people all sniff the same sample. Only about 1 out of 20 seem to be able to detect the odor.

results.notes:
A NEMF Foray collection for a MycoFlora sequencing project. NAMP collection MF54407.
A small bolete collected by Rob Handel in pine litter in mixed woods. It could be a Xerocomellus sp., but the cap is not cracked, and the stipe sports an interesting texture consisting of longitudinal ridges and some scruffiness. The copious yellow basal mycelium is also noteworthy. Boletaceae is perhaps a better name for it at this time.
DNA Sequencing Results & Discussion (posted 2-May-21):
> A clean and contiguous nrDNA sequence of 749 base pairs (bps) was obtained from this collection by MycoFlora/FunDiS; it was edited by me and posted to this observation; it was also published in GenBank (accession #MW882071). It consists of a full-length consensus nrITS sequence of 665 characters derived from forward and reverse reads (ITS = 197 bps, 5.8S = 161 bps, ITS2 = 307 bps) flanked on its left and right by the last 46 nucleotides of nrSSU and the first 88 bps of nrLSU. There are three ambiguous positions: “R” (A/G) in ITS1 and ITS2 and “Y” (C/T) in 5.8S.
> A BLASTn-100 of the full-length ITS sequence returned 7 accessions derived from eastern North American vouchers having 96.8-99.4% similarity (all but one with 94-100% query cover). I think are the same species. Two of these, JX030249 and KM213665, have been identified as Xerocomellus truncatus in Frank et al. (2020), the first DNA-informed study of North American Xerocomellus with a focus on western NA taxa.1
Accessions MW448631 and MW448633 are respectively associated with Alden Dirks’ obs 323434 and obs 323436 from Wisconsin. These are the ones with 98.6% similarity in ITS to the present observation. Alignment of these sequences is shown in Fig. 1. As can be seen, the only main difference is the presence of a 17 bps indel in the WI sequences; the four scattered mismatches can be ignored because they involve ambiguities. Hence, I think Alden’s vouchers are also Xerocomellus truncatus.
> Long ITS1 and ITS2 fragments derived from my obs 285192 collected in northern NJ (data to be posted soon) are both a 100% match to the corresponding regions in the ITS of the present post. That collection features spores with truncate apices, which also supports X. truncatus.
Reference:
1 Free access at https://www.researchgate.net/...

results.notes:
A NEMF Foray collection for a MycoFlora sequencing project. NAMP collection MF54409.
A small immature red-pored bolete found by Terri Hungerford in a grassland habitat (presumably near oaks). Unfortunately, by the time the mushroom made it to the sorting tables, it’s been discolored.

DNA Sequencing Results and Discussion (first draft: 15-Apr-21; final version: 24-Apr-21):
> A clean and contiguous nrDNA sequence of 712 base pairs (bps) was obtained from this material by MycoFlora/FunDiS in July 2019. [Because MF/FDS sequences are known to contain occasional errors (auto editing done by software, not a human), I analyzed and edited the raw .ab1 files myself.] The sequence consists of the first 46 bps of nrSSU, followed by the full-length nrITS spacer of 628 bps and then by the first 38 bps of nrLSU. The ITS1 and ITS2 subloci are 240 and 227 bps long, respectively, whereas the highly conserved 5.8S region is of the standard length of 161 bps. There are three ambiguous positions present; all are “Y” (C/T).

> Subsequent to the discovery and sequencing of this voucher, 6 more suspected red-pored and reticulated collections of presumable this taxon have been reported on Mushroom Observer (MO) by different users and pursued by me: obs 330793, obs 334282, obs 380038, obs 383792, obs 426057, and obs 427156. Their phylogenetic identities vis-a-vis MO327823 have been established by DNA sequencing (nrITS), courtesy of Dr. Linas Kudzma. With exception of MO330793, all turned out to be conspecific with MO327823 (vide infra). Presently, the distribution range of North American of these two North American Suillellus appears to be restricted to the northern tier of the USA and southern Canada, making it a boreal taxon, although MO380038 was collected in northern Ohio (same latitude as far northern New Jersey).

> Alignment of the 6 ITS sequences of the present taxon is shown in Fig. 1. Although there are, in total, 8 mismatching positions shared by these collections to varying extent, 6 of these can be disregarded because they involve ambiguities; 2 of these happen to be fully polymorphic sites. The remaining 2 mismatches that don’t involve ambiguities are naturally occurring single nucleotide polymorphisms (SNPs); however, it’s possible other populations of this taxon might feature ambiguities at these positions. There is no question these 6 collections are conspecific.

> In GenBank, this entity is currently represented by 5 accessions (99-99.8% similar to MO327823), all derived from North American vouchers. Four of these are labeled as ‘Boletales sp.’ and one as ‘Suillellus luridus’ (incorrectly). Published authentic ITS accessions of Suillellus luridus of Europe are only 95-96% similar to those of the present taxon, suggesting close kinship (GenBank BLASTn-100 data). ITS sequence alignment of MO327823 and my personal collection of Suillellus luridus from Lithuania, obs 379950, is shown in Fig. 2. At the same time, the observed barcoding gap, (i.e., “the difference between inter- and intraspecific genetic distances within a group of organisms”), is wide, suggesting that this North American taxon is not conspecific with Suillellus luridus of the Old World. ITS sequences of other Suillellus species reported in GenBank are more genetically distant (BLASTn data).

> Phylogenetically, MO327823 appears as a sister taxon of Suillellus luridus in distance-based and maximum likelihood (ML) trees (Figs. 3 & 4, respectively). Statistical support for each species, as well as their kinship, is substantial in the ML tree.

> Microscopically, the present taxon can also be readily separated from Suillellus luridus of Europe by spore size and shape. For the only mature collection in my possession, obs 427156, I recorded the following spore data: (8.4-) 8.8~12.1 (-12.6) x (4.9-) 5.1~6.7 (-7.0) m; Q = 1.5~2.0 (-2.05).1 The reported spore data for Suillellus luridus in European literature are 10.515.5 4.57 m, Q = 1.82.8.2.

> It’s possible the present species may have already been described as new to science and endemic to North America by a mycologist of the past. If so, buried in some old literature, it awaits rediscovery. For example, a brief search of the polyphyletic Boletus sect. Luridi in The Boletes of Michigan yielded the obscure and forgotten Boletus vinaceobasis A.H. Sm. & Thiers as a possible candidate for the present species.3 Known only from a single collection, its macroscopic description and spore measurements appear to be in line with the corresponding features of the present taxon.4 However, before any firm conclusions can be drawn about its identity and relationship to the present species, further study of the B. vinaceobasis holotype and/or topotype/epitype particularly their genetic characterization are needed. Therefore, at this time I would like to propose Suillellus ameriluridus I. Safonov & Kudzma nom. prov. as a placeholder name for the present taxon. I feel this move is justified in light of the molecular data, the existence of more than one prominently reticulated Suillellus species in northeastern North America confirmed by DNA sequencing (i.e., MO330793), and a recent report of yet to be sequenced obs 412820 / obs 413065 from Virginia.
References:
1 A portion of the tube layer of MO427156 was crushed in a small vial and extracted with 5% KOH. An aliquot of this extract was subjected to a microscopic analysis. Forty (40) spores in the profile (dorsi-ventral) orientation were measured at x1000.
2 https://boletales.com/genera/boletus/b-luridus/
3 A.H. Smith & H.D. Thiers, The Boletes of Michigan: pp. 347-348 (1971)
4 The dried holotype of B. vinaceobasis can be visualized here: https://quod.lib.umich.edu/...

Collected by Beth Karwowski in mixed woods.
This is likely one of the numerous morpho-forms of the common oak-loving relative of B. subvelutipes Peck. The cap color of this species (or species group that cannot be resolved by LSU & TEF-1) is very variable, ranging from pure golden yellow to pale orange to orangish-brown to dark tawny (fox red); the stipe color is also variable, but the background is always yellow, with a variable amount of red to reddish-brown puncatae, and burgundy staining at the base.

results.notes:
A NEMF Foray collection for a MycoFlora sequencing project. NAMP collection MF54411.
Two collections of what appears to be the same species by Joel Horman and Gene Binder from the same walk merged together.
The stipital ornamentation varied from the typical variobrunneus netting in older/more mature specimens to almost no reticulation at all in young ones. Furthermore, younger basidiomes had a dense medium-brown woolly squamulose-scabrous ornamentation at the apex, which I’ve never seen to occur in Tylopilus. Both collections had these peculiar fruiting bodies.
Overall I think variobrunneus is a reasonable proposal, but I wouldn’t call this morpho-gestalt typical of the species based on my own experience with it.
This collection is conspecific with obs 327818 (from MI) by ITS.

A NEMF Foray collection for a MycoFlora sequencing project. NAMP collection MF54412.
Collected by Ulli Kulik (spelling?). I have no further information on this material from the collector.
The single photo provides a good presentation of the morphology. The pores bruised blue. This species looks different from all the other suspected Hortiboletus and Xerocomellus entities collected at this NEMF Foray and posted by me to MO for the NAMP project; however, it could be the same species as MF54401/obs 327553 that has been tentatively ID by me as B. subfraternus.

DNA Sequencing Results & Discussion (posted on 25-Apr-21):
> This collection was ITS sequenced by MycoFlora in 2019. After a manual edit of the forward and reverse reads, the resultant consensus nrDNA sequence is 797 base pairs (bps) long. It consists of the last 46 bps of nrSSU, followed by a full-length nrITS region of 713 bps and then by the first 38 characters of nrLSU. The ITS1 and ITS2 subloci in this species are 236 and 316 nucleotides long, respectively; the 5.8S region sandwiched between the ITS spacers is of the standard conserved length of 161 bps. There are two ambiguities at positions nos. 113 (“Y” = C/T) and 417 (“S” = C/G). The sequence has been accessioned in GenBank and just posted to this observation.
This bolete is conspecific with another NEMF collection, obs 327553, by ITS (99.44% similar). There are four mismatches in the overlay of the full-length ITS sequences: the two aforementioned ambiguities and two pyrimidine-type (C/T) SNP events at positions nos. 66 and 622.
> A BLASTn-100 of the full-length ITS sequence recovered no matches or close hits. The top 4 accessions are only 90-91% similar, but query lengths dont exceed 78%. Two of these are accessions of Hortiboletus coccyginus (KU144818 & KU144819), which make this rare bolete from the West Coast the closest relative in terms of genetic distance values.
> Looking at the morphology of this collection and the BLASTn profile, placement in Hortiboletus is a possibility. However, morphologically I wouldnt call this species a dead ringer for this genus. Furthermore, lack of Hortiboletus sp. hits from eastern North America is perplexing. For example, the full-length ITS sequence the common eastern Hortiboletus taxon, represented on MO by the sequenced obs 373444 and obs 418487, is only 81% similar.
> Based on the above information, provisional placement of this species into the subfamily Boletoideae seems more reasonable at this time. Further molecular research is needed for a phylogenetic placement at the genus level. However, since I deposited MO327553 and MO327973 at the NYBG herbarium, additional collections of this rare entity are required.
